com.bluegosling.collections

Class MoreIterables

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.bluegosling.collections.MoreIterables

  • public final class MoreIterables
extends Object
    Utility methods for working with and creating instances of Iterable. These methods complement those in Guava's Iterables class.

    • Method Detail

      • asCollection

        public static <E> Collection<E> asCollection(Iterable<E> iter)
        Returns a view of the given iterable as a collection. If the given iterable already implements Collection then it is returned. Otherwise, an unmodifiable collection view is returned. The return view may require linear time to compute the size (by actually performing an iteration and counting elements).
        Type Parameters:
        E - the type of elements in the collection
        Parameters:
        iter - an iterable
        Returns:
        a view of the given iterable as a collection

      • comparator

        public static <E> Comparator<Iterable<E>> comparator(Comparator<? super E> comparator)
        Returns a comparator of iterables based on the given comparator of elements. The returned comparator will order iterables in pseudo-lexical order, as if each element were a character in a string. So it first compares the first element from two iterables. If those are equal then it must compare the next elements and so on. If the end of one iterable is encountered first, then the shorter one (which is a strict prefix of the longer one) is considered less than the longer one.
        Type Parameters:
        E - the type of element being compared
        Parameters:
        comparator - a comparator of elements
        Returns:
        a corresponding comparator of iterables

      • unique

        public static <E> Iterable<E> unique(Iterable<E> iter)
        Returns an iterable that omits duplicates from the given iterable. Note that the tracking of duplicates requires state that can use O(n) amount of memory for each iteration.
        Type Parameters:
        E - the type of elements in the iterable
        Parameters:
        iter - an iterable
        Returns:
        an iterable that returns the items of the given iterable but omits duplicates

      • reversed

        public static <E> Iterator<E> reversed(Iterable<E> iterable)
        Returns an iterator that navigates over the given iterable in reverse order. Most iterables do not provide an efficient way to do this, in which case a stack is used (and thus will require O(n) amount of memory). But for those that do provide efficient implementations (like lists, deques, and navigable sets) they will be used so there is no space overhead.
        Type Parameters:
        E - the type of elements in the iterable
        Parameters:
        iterable - an iterable
        Returns:
        an iterator that visits the elements of the iterable in reverse order

      • trySize

        public static OptionalInt trySize(Iterable<?> iterable)
        Queries for the size of the given iterable, if known. If the given iterable implements Collection then the size is returned. Otherwise, an absent value is returned, indicating that the size is not known.
        Parameters:
        iterable - an iterable
        Returns:
        the size of the given iterable if known
        See Also:
        Iterables.size(Iterable), Iterators.size(Iterator)

      • snapshot

        public static <E> Collection<E> snapshot(Iterable<? extends E> iterable)
        Creates a snapshot of the given iterable. This involves iterating over the elements and creating an unmodifiable collection with all of its contents.

        The snapshot is created with as little overhead as possible using a strategy like used by ArrayList, except using linked nodes of arrays (each larger than the previous) instead of resizing a single array (so no copies need be made when the initial array gets full). The initial array is sized based on the given iterable's size or 16 if the size is unknown.

        The returned snapshot is just a collection. If you need a snapshot that implements the List or Set interface, use ImmutableList.copyOf(Iterable) or ImmutableSet.copyOf(Iterable).

        Parameters:
        iterable - an iterable
        Returns:
        a snapshot of the iterable's contents in an unmodifiable collection
        See Also:
        MoreIterators.snapshot(Iterator)

      • toArray

        public static Object[] toArray(Iterable<?> iterable)
        Creates a snapshot of the given iterable as an array. Implementations that already have a toArray method, like Collection, will just use that existing implementation.

        Iterables that do not provide such a method must resort to a custom mechanism. A snapshot of the iterable is captured, and then a new array is created from the contents of that snapshot. So there is O(n) memory overhead, in addition to the O(n) memory needed by the returned array.

        Parameters:
        iterable - an iterable
        Returns:
        a snapshot of the iterable's contents in an array
        See Also:
        Collection.toArray(), MoreIterators.toArray(Iterator), toArray(Iterable, Object[]), Iterables.toArray(Iterable, Class)

      • toArray

        public static <T> T[] toArray(Iterable<?> iterable,
                              T[] array)
        Creates a snapshot of the given iterable as an array of the given type. The given array is used if it is large enough. If it is too large, a null terminator will be written to the location after the end of the given iterable's contents. If it is too small, a new array with the same component type will be allocated and returned.
        Parameters:
        iterable - an iterable
        array - an array
        Returns:
        a snapshot of the iterable's contents in an array
        See Also:
        Collection.toArray(Object[]), MoreIterators.toArray(Iterator, Object[]), toArray(Iterable), Iterables.toArray(Iterable, Class)

      • cast

        public static <E> Iterable<E> cast(Iterable<? extends E> iterable)
        Casts the given iterable to one whose elements are a super-type.
        Parameters:
        iterable - an iterable
        Returns:
        the given iterable, but with a generic type that is a super-type of the one given

      • flatMap

        public static <T,U> Iterable<U> flatMap(Iterable<T> iterable,
                                        Function<? super T,? extends Iterator<? extends U>> fn)
        Expands the given sequence using the given function. Each element in the given iterable is transformed into another sequence via the function. The resulting iterable concatenates all such resulting sequences.
        Parameters:
        iterable - an iterable
        fn - a function that expands each element into another sequence
        Returns:
        an iterable that has the results of expanding each element
